column1: One of four, where dragon's may be slayed, the constitution is strong where two have been laid.
Imposing in size and looking particularly mean, to find this old lockup just find a magazine.
Once a half-moon, then a more civic exchange. Its now open to all at the end of a broad range.
column2: The Old Exchange and Provost Dungeon

column1: Originally designed to have its top to be blown, the oldest public building in Carolina now known.
A multitude of reasons for their various hues, if you know Charleston you need no more clues.
This shameful part of our history is still visible today, on this bumpy road slaves were once on display.
A Dock now a Queen crossed with a Church, here is place where lines are rehearsed.
He was the first, now in Charleston a square. His D.C's companion also resides there.
column2: Washington Square and Washington Light Infantry monument

column1: The second eldest in all of the town, where the headstones are covered and fading into the ground.
Undo this anagram to find this famous house, the answer you'll find in "Agreed Who Ousts".
Find this man who looks over the water he once defended, towards his namesake fort where the Royal Navy was rended.
24,000 plus feet and over 50 feet tall, this monstrous manse also has a room for a ball.
The southern-most part of the old city wall, where history is preserved and shared with all.
A slightly newer exchange north of the old, almost 30 years to make, build and mold.
Built by a signer of independence in 1772, it shares a name with the father of our country too.
Find a gazebo white and round, where oysters once laid, till a wall was built around.
Occupied by the brits and yanks to boot, follow to the bottom of a king is the route.
A sign of hospitality in old Charles Town, this one is metal where water falls down.
